clinical_study.brief_title: Escalating Temporary Gastric Electrical Stimulation (GES) for Severe Gastroparesis
clinical_study.official_title: Escalating Temporary Gastric Electrical Stimulation for Severe Gastroparesis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the physiologic effects of temporary gastric electrical stimulation in subjects with severe gastroparesis.

detailed_description.textblock: This study will look to determine the clinical benefit placing temporary gastric electrical stimulation, the ability to predict the clinical response to surgical implantation of GES, and the feasibility and patient tolerability of endoscopic placement of temporary Gastric Electrical Stimulator (t-GES),

primary_outcome.measure: Improvement in the symptoms of gastroparesis by t-GES in patients with severe gastroparesis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical response to t-GES placement as measured by questionnaires
Develop a prospective registry in patients undergoing escalating t-GES
determine the feasibility and patient tolerability of endoscopic placement of t-GES

study_pop.textblock: Subjects who have been diagnosed with gatroparesis.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 3 months of gastroparesis-related symptoms, such as nausea, emesis, and/or retching
- Solid phase 4-hr gastric scintigraphy is consistent with gastroparesis within 3 months of study enrollment*
- retention at 2 hr: >60% or
- retention at 4 hr: >10% *Based on International consensus on gastric scintigraphy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Gastric outlet, small bowel, or colon obstruction.
- Small bowel malrotation
- Inflammatory bowel disease
- Contraindication for surgical implantation of GES
- Presence of illness that may require MRI during the study; such as pituitary tumor, herniated disc, spinal stenosis, multiple sclerosis, etc.
- Significant comorbidity due to sever cardiovascular, renal, pulmonary, or liver disease.
- Significant coagulopathy
- Non-ambulatory patients: bed-ridden, nursing home resident, etc.
- Pregnancy
- Unable to give own informed consent
- Prisoners
